title: Newton third law FBD for two blocks

content.question: The figures shown here are top-view force diagrams when the blocks are at the position shown in the original figure. The arrows represent the horizontal forces exerted on the blocks. The frictional force from the wall is represented by <math alttext="lowercase f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, the normal force from the wall is represented by <math alttext="N" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>N</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, the force the blocks exerted on each other is represented by <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the horizontal pushing force exerted on block <math alttext="uppercase A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is represented by <math alttext="uppercase F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following describes evidence from the figures that supports Newtonâ€™s third law?

choices.label: The arrows for <math alttext="lowercase f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are in the same direction on each block.
The arrows for the force <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are the same size and in opposite directions on the two blocks.

The arrow for <math alttext="uppercase F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on block <math alttext="uppercase A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is about the size of the addition of the arrows for <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="lowercase f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on block <math alttext="uppercase A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
The arrows for <math alttext="N" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>N</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are in the same direction for both blocks.

The arrows for the forces <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="lowercase f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on block <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are the same size and in opposite directions.

content.answer: The arrows for the force <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are the same size and in opposite directions on the two blocks.

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
